Fig. 1 (a) comparison of NH3-SCR activity over various catalysts, (b) effect of Mn/Ce ratios on NH3-SCR activity over the serial catalysts, (c) GHSV=90,000 h −1; (d) GHSV=120,000 h −1, (e) effect of H2O at 200 °C with GHSV = 60,000 h −1 on NH3-SCR activity over the serial catalysts, (f) tests for resistance to SO2 and H2O poisoning over the serial catalysts. The resource utilization of Cr-containing leather waste is still a great challenge. In this work, waste from leather production as raw material was attempted to be used to synthesize activated carbon, a series of MnxCe1-xZr0.5/AC composite catalysts were prepared via loading three metal elements onto activated carbon by impregnation method, the NH3-SCR performance was measured in a low temperature range of 50 ∼ 200 °C. Among them, the catalyst Mn0.7Ce0.3Zr0.5/AC displays the optimal low-temperature SCR activity, excellent resistance to GHSV, H2O and SO2. The characterization results indicated that increasing the Mn/Ce inequality ratios within a certain range would promote the electron transfer between the active metal components, thereby enhancing the synergistic effect and the redox capacity of the catalysts, and it also could significantly improve the concentration of Lewis acid sites to accelerate the adsorption and activation of NH3, resulting in different catalytic activities. The in situ DRIFTS results prove that the Lewis acid site plays a vital role in the “fast SCR” reaction, and the whole reaction process conforms to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Leather waste Activated carbon Metal-modification NH3-SCR Metal synergies Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction As one of the main pollutants in the atmosphere [1,2], NOx mainly comes from coal combustion, automobile exhaust emission, etc. and bring numerous environmental troubles such as photochemical smog and acid rain [3]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxides using NH3 is the most efficient industrial technology to control NOx emissions [4]. At present, the traditional commercialized SCR catalyst is V2O5-WO3 (MoO3)/TiO2 (anatase) [5–7]. But some shortcomings also appear in recent years including high energy consumption, narrow active temperature window (350 ∼ 450 °C), and unsatisfactory stability [8,9], which limits its further application. Especially, in recent years, the requirement of “Ultra-low emission” and cost reduction call for the development of high-efficiency SCR catalysts with excellent low-temperature catalytic ability [10]. Catalysts based on transition metals gradually have been a research hotspot for several years. MnOx, MnOx-CeO2/TiO2 [11] or MnOx-CeO2 supported on carbon-based carrier substance [12–14] (activated carbon, activated carbon fibers, carbon nanotubes, and honeycomb activated carbon, etc.) have been commonly exploited as low-temperature SCR catalysts. Due to the reason that cerium can store and release oxygen through the transformation of its own valence state to form more unstable oxygen vacancies and free radicals, while Mn has various valences, including + 2, + 3, + 4, + 5 and some non-integer equivalents due to the special valence electron configuration (3d54s2), the mutual conversion between different valence states facilitates the formation of surface-active oxygens species, which consequently benefits the SCR activity [15,16]. In addition, when Mn and Ce are coexisted in the same system, Mn may enter into the lattice of CeO2 to replace part of the Ce atoms, so that the lattice of CeO2 will be distorted to form solid solutions or new crystalline phases resulting in better catalytic performance via inducing interactions [17,18]. Additionally, it is widely accepted that muti-metal doping can induce a synergistic effect via inhibiting the sintering of active metals to a certain degree, improving the dispersion of active components, which consequently promote the SCR reaction cycle [19]. For example, Yang et al. [20] reported that Fe-Mn composite oxides synthesized by co-precipitation method, owns optimal low-temperature catalytic activity and high N2 selectivity due to the synergistic effect between Fe and Mn. Kang et al. [21] prepared an unsupported Cu-Mn composite catalyst, their results showed that the catalyst achieved nearly 100 % NOx conversion at 50 ∼ 200 °C since the existence of solid solution. Long et al. [22] synthesized three mixed oxides catalysts including Mn-Fe, Mn-Zr and Mn-Fe-Zr via coprecipitation, and evaluated the low-temperature catalytic ability at 100 ∼ 180 °C. They found that the synergistic effect between elements could make the NO removal rate at 180 °C reach to nearly 100 % at a space velocity of 15,000 h−1, and revealed that the introduction of Zr could significantly enhance the thermal stability and anti-poisoning ability of the catalysts due to the enhanced crystallinity of the active components. Similar conclusions are found in others reports [23,24]. In general, the catalytic performance of the Mn-Ce based catalysts may be significantly improved by introducing some metal elements. However, the sintering phenomenon has been a prominent problem in the fabrication of metal oxide catalysts, in which case loading catalysts have received much attention. Compared with TiO2 support, activated carbon (AC) has some unique advantages including larger specific surface area, higher adsorption capacity, and abundant functional groups, which are critical for the promotion of the SCR reaction [25–27]. The activated carbon carrier used in this work was derived from leather waste by considering its negative impact on the environment and human beings. At present, the chrome tanning is the mainstream technology in the tanning process, which results in the generation of a large amounts of chrome-containing wastes [28,29]. The main components of leather waste are collagen, trivalent chromium in the form of chromium oxide, fats and other inorganic substances and impurity metals (such as Fe, Mg, etc.), their contents are approximately 80 %, 4 %, 10.5 % and 5.5 % in kilobases, respectively [30]. In fact, the current resource utilization of leather waste is mainly reflected in the recovery of chromium from leather waste through incineration. Although this method realizes the resource utilization of leather waste to a certain extent, it also induces some new problems such as incomplete recycling, serious secondary pollution [31]. In summary, it's a waste of resources and makes harm to the environment if the Cr-containing leather wastes are ignored. Therefore, the handing of the Cr-containing leather wastes is a key issue that severely restricts the healthy development of the leather industry, realizing the resource utilization of Cr-containing leather wastes is an important research direction to solve the above problems. Considering the fact that the leather wastes are mainly composed of protein, the use of Cr-containing leather wastes to prepare activated carbon for catalytic carrier may be a new resource utilization approach, which could solve the problem of leather waste treatment and provides assistance to solve environmental problems [32,33]. In this study, activated carbon with high specific surface area and developed void structure was prepared by using Cr-containing leather waste as raw material as a carrier, a multi-metal/activated carbon catalyst was synthesized via loading cerium, manganese, and zirconium, the ratios of Mn/Ce in the catalyst were adjusted to improve the low-temperature de-NOx ability, and SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and XPS were employed to characterize the structures of these samples. In addition, to gain an insight into the impact mechanism of Mn/Ce ratios on the reaction path, in-situ DRIFTS was adopted. This work may provide the possibility for the commercial application of this Cr-containing leather waste based stationary source SCR catalyst in the future. Experiment Catalyst synthesis The preparation of activated carbon from leather waste mainly includes four steps: pulverization, acid pretreatment, carbonization, and activation. By soaking the leather powder in a high concentration hydrochloric acid to remove impurities, drying and calcinated in a tube furnace at 600 °C in N2 atmosphere for carbonization, then the obtained raw leather carbon was ground and mixed with KOH solid, and subsequently activated at 800 °C in N2 atmosphere to obtain the desired activated carbon. Different proportions of Mn, Ce, Zr were loaded on the obtained activated carbon by impregnation method. The total loading was 5 % of the mass of the activated carbon, the amount of Zr was fixed with being 0.5 % of the mass of the carrier. Preparation of different catalysts were performed by changing the Mn/Ce ratios. As a matter of convenience of expression, the activated carbon without metal oxide and the catalyst loaded with single metal oxide were labeled as AC, AC-Ce and AC-Mn, respectively. Meanwhile, the composite catalysts were named as Mn0.8Ce0.2AC, Mn0.7Ce0.3AC, Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, Mn0.4Ce0.6AC and Mn0.3Ce0.7AC, respectively, according to the Mn/Ce ratio (mass ratios of Mn: Ce is 8:2, 7:3, 6:4, 4:6, 3:7) since the content of Zr was fixed in each composite metal oxide. Catalyst activity evaluation The evaluation of catalytic activity was expressed in the supporting information. Catalyst characterization The characterization measurement of as-synthesized catalysts and in-situ DRIFTS of MnxCe1-xZr0.5/AC are expressed in the supporting information. Results and discussion Catalyst activity Fig. 1 (a) shows the NOx conversion curves over AC, AC-Ce, AC-Mn, and Mn0.7Ce0.3AC catalysts under the reaction temperature (50 ∼ 200 °C). It can be noticed that AC exhibits some ternary NO conversion over the whole temperature range, with a maximum catalytic efficiency of no more than 30 %. The catalytic conversion NOx ability was significantly upgraded after the introduction of Mn and Ce, suggesting that Mn and Ce are active for NH3-SCR reaction in the Mn-Ce/AC system. Additionally, the catalytic activity of AC-Mn (maximum NOx conversion above 70 %) was significantly better than that of ACCe (maximum NOx conversion below 70 %), illustrating that Mn-based catalysts can exhibit higher NH3-SCR catalytic performance at low temperature, as reported in the literatures [34,35]. Compared with others, Mn0.7Ce0.3AC displays the optimal catalytic activity with the highest NOx conversion (97 %, 200 °C). The results proved that the bimetallic combination is highly beneficial to improve the catalytic activity. A similar finding was reported by Yuan et al. [36]. Fig. 1(b) reveals the influence of Mn/Ce ratios on the NH3-SCR performance over MnxCe1-xZr0.5/AC catalysts. It can be observed that the Mn/Ce ratios have an important impact on the catalytic ability. The conversion of NO improved gradually as the Mn/ (Mn + Ce) mass ratio increased from 0.4 to 0.7, but the catalytic behavior was negatively affected when the ratio was further increased to 0.8. Not only that, the catalytic activity showed a certain rise when the Mn/ (Mn + Ce) mass ratio was reduced to 0.3. Obviously, 97 % NO conversion was achieved at 200 °C for the Mn/ (Mn + Ce) mass ratio of 0.7. Chang et al. [37] founded that MnOx-CeO2 catalyst has high deNOx ability in a wide temperature range of 80 °C ∼ 230 °C, whose NO removal rate is as high as 98 ∼ 100 %. The deNOx comparison of the as-synthesized carbon-based catalysts in this work with that in the literatures as previously reported were summarized in Table 1 . In contrast, Mn0.7Ce0.3AC is competitively available due to its high deNOx performance. The NO oxidation reaction tests were also performed on the samples before and after modification to investigate the effect of Mn/Ce ratios on the oxidation ability, as shown in Fig. S1. The low-temperature NO oxidation ability is significantly improved compared to the raw AC, suggesting that the active components adopted are active for the NO oxidation reaction. At the same time, the order of the catalysts' oxidation activity is well consistent with that of the standard SCR reaction, revealing that the metals co-doping with inequality Mn/Ce ratios can greatly affect the NO oxidation ability of the as-gained catalysts, consequently determining the low temperature NH3-SCR reaction. As the GHSV was increased to 90,000 h −1 and 120,000 h −1, the NO conversion appeared to be reduced to varying extent, with a maximum reduction rate of about 51 % (Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, 120,000 h −1, 200 °C). In comparison with other catalysts, it is still more than 70 % removal efficiency 200 °C for Mn0.7Ce0.3AC, suggesting that it has good resistance ability to space velocity. The order of the catalytic activity in general remains consistent with Mn0.7Ce0.3AC > Mn0.3Ce0.7AC > Mn0.4Ce0.6AC > Mn0.6Ce0.4AC. It is well known that the catalyst's resistance ability to H2O and SOx should be taken into account in practical application, therefore, the corresponding tests were carried out, as shown in Fig. 1(e) and (f). The NOx conversion of the catalyst at 200 °C suffered a reduction with varying degrees after the introduction of H2O, which was mainly due to the competition adsorption of the reactive gasses and H2O [38,39], as shown in Fig. 1(e). It could be observed that the Mn0.7Ce0.3AC exhibited a good resistance to water, only 10 % decline in catalytic activity. And the NOx conversion gradually recovered to the original level with the water vapor turning off, suggesting that the poisoning was reversible. As shown in Fig. 1(f), it was found that the catalytic performance of these catalysts after sulfuration was reduced to some extent, but Mn0.7Ce0.3AC still showed excellent catalytic activity with the 90 % NOx conversion at 200 °C, indicative of a good resistance ability to SO2 and H2O poisoning. The catalytic performance of Mn0.7Ce0.3AC was recovered to some extent but could not completely back to its original level after thermal regeneration through calcining the poisoned catalyst at 550 °C under nitrogen protection as shown in Fig. S2, which implies that Mn0.7Ce0.3AC has good resistance ability to poisoning. Textural characterization SEM and N2 physisorption The SEM pattens of the leather activated carbon in Fig. 2 show that a rich pore structure of the as-prepared activated carbon exists mainly in the form of irregular lumps, which should mainly be attributed to the contribution of chemical activation and was favorable for the loading of active metals. Meanwhile, it can be inferred from Table 1 and Fig. S3 that the raw activated carbon exhibits a huge specific surface area (1489 m2 g−1) which facilitates the availability of more reactive sites, abundant pore structure (0.86 cm3 g−1) and an average pore diameter of 0.55 nm (close to the molecular size of reactive gas). Based on potential energy theory, the smaller pore size and larger BET surface area are favorable for the enhancement of catalyst adsorption capacity, which makes the reactive gasses easily selective absorption by the pores when the pore diameter is close to the absorbent size, and thus promote the SCR reaction [40]. The nitrogen adsorption curves shown in Fig. S4(a) indicate that the adsorption isotherm of leather activated carbon belongs to type I according to the classification of IUPAC adsorption and desorption isotherm, meaning the presence of numerous micropores. The pore size distribution diagram derived from the HK method in Fig. S4(b) displays that organized carbon pore size is mainly 0.6 nm, implying that the Mn/Ce ratios make some impact on the pore diameter of the as-synthesized catalysts during calcination process. As shown in Table 2 , the introduction of metal oxides would significantly reduce the specific surface area, micropore specific surface area and total pore volume, the pore structure of Mn0.6Ce0.4AC is most affected while Mn0.7Ce0.3AC is the least influenced, which is probably related with the formation of oxide nanoparticles within the pore structure of the AC. The above analysis suggests that Me/Ce ratio may influence the contact of the adsorbed gas with the active site through pore structure, resulting in differences in catalytic efficiency. XRD XRD was used to detect the change of crystal phase as shown in Fig. 3 , and the diffraction peaks of Mn3O4, Ce2O3 and carbon are detected in this spectrum. The two broad diffraction peaks of (0 0 2) and (1 0 0) crystal planes are monitored in all catalysts which attributed to the amorphous carbon. Among them, the (0 0 2) diffraction peak at around 30° represents the presence of graphite microcrystals with a layered structure, which helps to oxidize NO to NO2 and favors the “fast SCR” reaction at low temperature since the coexisting of NO and NO2 according to the study, and the (1 0 0) diffraction peak at 40 ∼ 45° reflecting a turbulent graphite-like structure [41]. It could be observed that the diffraction peak of (0 0 2) and (1 0 0) weaken with the introduction of metal oxides, which suggests that the degree of catalyst arylation and the size of the aromatic planar molecules are affected. Well-dispersed active phases were proven to be able to ameliorate the structural properties of the catalyst [48], which is in accordance with the BET results. The diffraction peaks at 37.5°, 42.8° to 45.8° and 48.6° are significantly affected by the Mn/Ce ratios. And diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 35.4°, 57° and 62.3° were well matched with the tetragonal Mn3O4 (JCPDS No.24–0734) [49], and its intensity increased significantly with the Mn loading indicating the enhancement of the crystallinity of Mn3O4, this phenomenon is also present in the variation of the diffraction peak located at 2θ = 30.3° which was attributed to cubic CeO2 (JCPDS No.23–1048). However, the diffraction peaks assigned to ZrOx species are not detected in the serial diffraction patterns, indicative of the homogeneously dispersed of ZrOx on the catalyst surface [50]. In summary, Mn/Ce ratios could impact the crystallization of the composite oxides, thereby affecting the de-NOx ability. NH3-TPD analyses The key of NH3-SCR lies in the adsorption and activation of NH3 at acidic sites on the catalyst surface, the NH3-TPD test was employed to analyze the surface acidity. As is present in Fig. 4 (a), all of the four NH3-TPD curves can be fitted into four parts, which are below 200 °C, 200 ∼ 400 °C, 400 ∼ 600 °C and above 600 °C, respectively. The peaks below 200 °C are attached to weakly acidic sites while the peaks at 200 ∼ 400 °C are derived from medium acid sites, and the peaks at 400 ∼ 600 °C and above 600 °C are medium-strong acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively [51,52]. The peaks below 400 °C are assigned to the desorption of NH3 on weak Brønsted acid sites while those above could be corresponded to NH3 desorption at Lewis acid sites since the thermal stability of NH3 molecules adsorbed on Lewis acid is stronger than NH4 + ions adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites reported in literatures [45,53]. All catalysts exhibit an abundant content of Lewis acidic sites which was demonstrated to sustain the high NO conversion and low N2O generation at low temperature. The proportion of Lewis acid is shown in Fig. 4(b), it could discover that the order is consistent with the catalytic activity which follows Mn0.7Ce0.3AC > Mn0.3Ce0.7AC > Mn0.4Ce0.6AC > Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, proving that Mn/Ce ratios could significantly affect the amount of Lewis acid sites since the greater this non-equivalent ratio, the higher the ratio of Lewis acidic sites, resulting in differences in the adsorption and activation rates of NH3 [41], which makes Mn0.7Ce0.3AC owns better NO conversion and might be a crucial factor affecting the catalytic behavior. Furthermore, the total acid amount calculated from fitted peak areas can be observed to be subject to the Mn/Ce ratios, but the order is not coinciding with that of the catalytic activity (Mn0.7Ce0.3AC > Mn0.4Ce0.6AC > Mn0.3Ce0.7AC > Mn0.6Ce0.4AC), suggesting that the total acid amount does not seem to be the main factor affecting the catalytic activity, but rather the magnitude of the Lewis acid. Additionally, the formation of Lewis acid sites seems to be highly related to the Mn/Ce ratios, specifically, the more the Mn/Ce ratio deviates from 1.0, the more favorable the generation of Lewis acid sites. It implies that the metals co-doping with inequality ratios of Mn/Ce are beneficial to the occurrence of interaction, which consequently promotes the generation of Lewis acid sites. The above analysis shows that the Mn/Ce ratio can significantly determine the amount of Lewis acid in the catalyst, which consequently impacts adsorption and activation of NH3, eventually affect the catalytic reaction cycle. H2-TPR and XPS analyses H2-TPR It is widely accepted that the deNOx ability of the SCR catalyst is highly related to the redox property [34,54,55]. Herein, the redox ability of Mn0.7Ce0.3AC, Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, Mn0.4Ce0.6AC and Mn0.3Ce0.7AC was investigated by H2-TPR, the curves and corresponding H2 consumption are shown in Fig. 5 (a) and (b). Three peaks appear in all catalysts after peak fitting. The peak below 400 °C was attributed to the reduction of MnO2 → Mn2O3 or surface adsorbed oxygen species (only observed on Mn0.4Ce0.6AC catalyst), which means Mn0.4Ce0.6AC owns a higher average oxidation state of Mn. The peaks at 500 ∼ 530 °C could also be ascribed to the partially reduction of Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 while the peaks at 580 ∼ 620 °C were assigned to Mn3O4 → MnO or Mn-O-Ce species [56], and peaks above 700 °C were presumed to the reduction of Ce4+ (not observed on Mn0.4Ce0.6AC catalyst, it might contribute to a lower vacancies concentration and oxygen species) [57,58]. Each reduction process of these catalysts and the total H2 consumption through quantitative analysis were shown in Fig. 5(b). The total H2 consumption of Mn0.4Ce0.6AC was significantly lower than those of other catalysts, while Mn0.7Ce0.3AC possessed the highest value, and the total H2 consumption shown in Fig. 5(b) is in the order of Mn0.7Ce0.3AC (3.4 mmol/g) > Mn0.3Ce0.7AC (2.7 mmol/g) > Mn0.4Ce0.6AC (2.3 mmol/g) > Mn0.6Ce0.4AC (1.3 mmol/g), which is consistent with the activity results, evidencing that there is a strong interaction between the active components, perhaps originating from the solid solution, which allows the reduction capacity of the catalyst to be improved and promotes the SCR reaction cycle. More importantly, the total H2 consumption is always dominated by the reduction peak at 580 - 620 °C and its variation was consistent with the order of the total H2 consumption, but not with the gradually decreasing Mn ratio. This phenomenon suggests that the metals co-doping with inequality ratio of Mn/Ce can promote the synergistic effect between the active metals, which may originate from the formation of Mn-O-Ce species or MnOx-CeO2 solid solutions. When this unequal ratio is larger within a certain range, the doping effect and connection between elements become more pronounced, which favors the mutual substitution of atoms and thus promotes the formation of solid solution, a similar result also have been found for Li et al. [59]. The above analysis proves that the synergistic effect between the active elements will notably promote the redox properties of the catalyst, the oxygen species content and thus benefit for the improvement of the catalytic performance. XPS analyses In order to further determine the element species and valence state, these catalysts were characterized by XPS. Fig. 6 is the peak spectrum of Mn 2p, Ce 3d, Zr 3d, O 1 s of each catalyst, and the element content is listed in Table 3 . The change of Mn, Ce, Zr element content is generally consistence with the theoretical change trend, and the difference from the theoretical content may be mainly due to the formation of solid solutions or the accumulation of elements on the catalyst surface. As is shown in Fig. S5, metal elements mainly exist in the form of MnOx, CeOx and ZrOx, respectively. From the C 1 s peak spectrum of all catalysts shown in Fig. S6, two characteristic peaks appear at the binding energy of 284.8 eV and 286 eV, belongs to CC and CO in activated carbon, respectively. Some studies [18,60] have proposed that graphene structure would influence the valence state of Mn and the presence of oxygen-bound carbon on the activated carbon surface could provide active sites for the connection of MnOx-CeOx-ZrOx, which is beneficial to promote the NH3-SCR reaction. From the peak spectrum of Mn 2p in Fig. 6(a), characteristic peaks at the binding energy of 640 ∼ 644 eV and 650 ∼ 660 eV correspond to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively. Among them, the characteristic peak with binding energy at 641.5 eV belongs to Mn3+, that at 642.6 eV and 654.5 eV belong to Mn4+, and the peak at 646 ± 1.0 eV is attributed to Mn2+ [61,62]. It has been reported that the coexistence of multiple-valence manganese oxides could enhance electron transfer and facilitate the SCR reaction [63]. The relative contents of Mn4+, Mn3+and Mn2+ are listed in Table 4 . It was found that the content of Mn4+ progressively rises with the decline in the proportion of Mn. Some studies believed that low-valence manganese (Mn3+, Mn2+) could generate more lattice defects and oxygen vacancies, resulting in stronger oxygen mobility and higher surface-active oxygen content, which in turn contributes to the improvement of redox ability and ultimately affects the SCR reaction [57,62,63]. This may be an important reason why the NO conversion performance of Mn0.7Ce0.3AC is better than others. In other words, the presence of manganese with different valences jointly promotes redox ability of the catalyst. More interestingly, it could be observed in Table S1 that the Mn2+peaks show a tendency to shift to higher binding energies as the Mn/Ce ratio decreases, indicative of the formation of Mn-CeOx solid solution, which makes the outer electrons of Mn transfer to Ce and further enhances the interaction between Mn and Ce, the above analysis was also supported by H2-TPR results. The Ce 3d peak spectrum in Fig. 6(b) can be fitted into five characteristic peaks at the binding energies of 883 eV, 886 eV, 901 eV, 904.7 eV, 917 eV, the characteristic peaks at 886 eV and 904.7 eV belong to Ce3+, while the peaks at 883 eV, 901 eV and 917 eV are attributed to Ce4+. A coexistence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species has been shown to induce charge imbalances, oxygen vacancies, and unsaturated chemical bonds, which favors the production of chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface [56]. Some studies [18,43] have proved that the presence of Ce3+ could induce electron imbalance on the catalyst surface, forming oxygen vacancies and unsaturated chemical bonds. And it is well-known that increasing the content of chemically adsorbed oxygen is beneficial to improve the SCR activity. Compared with Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, the ratio of Ce3+ on Mn0.7Ce0.3AC was higher, which could promote the redox cycle of Mn4++ Ce3+↔ Mn3+ + Ce4+, thus encouraged the NH3-SCR reaction [57]. Unsurprisingly, as shown in Table S1, with the increase of Ce concentration, the peaks at around 883 eV, 901 eV and 917 eV gradually shifted to the lower binding energy since the radius of Ce4+ is larger than Mnx+ and Zr4+, this phenomenon was in accordance with the studies of Venezia et al. [64], which may cause part of Mnx+ and Zr4+ to get into the Ce lattice to form solid solution and finally promote SCR reaction through synergistic effect. There are two characteristic peaks spectrum of Zr 3d5/2 at the binding energy of 182.7 eV and 185 eV (Fig. 6(c)), which is attributed to Zr4+. The change that both of its peaks tend to move to higher energy attests that there might be a synergistic effect between active components via forming a solid solution (Zr-CeOx or Mn-Zr-CeOx) once again, which is consistent with the XRD, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR results. Fig. 6(d) exhibits the peak spectrum of O 1 s. The characteristic peaks with binding energy at 530.2 eV, 531.9 eV, 533.1 eV can be corresponded to lattice oxygen (O2−, donated as α), chemisorbed oxygen (O2 −, O−, donated as β) and other oxygen species (hydroxyl, free oxygen, donated as γ), respectively [61,65]. The relative contents of α, β and γ on the catalyst surface were obtained according to the peak areas (Table 3). All catalysts presented abundant chemisorbed oxygen species since the order of the three oxygen species is: β > γ > α, which could favor the catalytic cycle due to the higher mobility. And it can be observed that the order of the content of chemically adsorbed oxygen (Mn0.7Ce0.3AC > Mn0.3Ce0.7AC > Mn0.4Ce0.6AC > Mn0.6Ce0.4AC) is highly consistent with the H2-TPR results, combined with the previous analysis, this suggests that when the non-equivalent ratios of co-doping with Mn and Ce is greater within a certain range, the electron transfer abilities between the metals are closer and more synergistic, which facilitates the generation of oxygen vacancies and the cycling of oxygen species [66,67]. Therefore, although Mn0.3Ce0.7AC also has a large unequal Mn/Ce ratio, it has less reactive oxygen species than Mn0.7Ce0.3AC, which may be the reason for its inferior catalytic activity. This order is also similar with activity results, since the chemisorbed oxygen is more likely to migrate and participate in SCR reaction compared with lattice oxygen and other oxygen species, which might be one explanation for its relatively higher SCR activity. In general, the catalytic ability of supported Mn-Ce-Zr mixed oxides is highly related to the low-valence Mn (Mn2+, Mn3+), chemisorbed oxygen and synergistic effect between metals. The valence state of the active component may undergo the following redox cycle during the catalytic process, which is strengthened with the widening of the Mn/Ce non-equivalent ratios: M n 4 + + C e 3 + ↔ M n 3 + + C e 4 + C e 3 + + M n 3 + ↔ M n 2 + + C e 4 + In situ DRIFTS spectra NH3 adsorption Fig. 7 displays the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption over Mn0.7Ce0.3AC, Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, Mn0.4Ce0.6AC, Mn0.3Ce0.7AC at 80 °C. Except for Mn0.6Ce0.4AC, there appeared several peaks at 947 cm−1, which attributed to the stretching vibration of N-H in NH2, it may be formed by the oxidation of adsorbed NH3 or ammonia species and make the difference in catalyst ability since -NH2 is usually identified as an important intermediate product of the NH3-SCR process [68]. The peaks in the interval of 3000 ∼ 3400 cm−1 are the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the NH bond in the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites and their intensity increased with adsorption time, while peaks above 3500 cm−1 are belonged to the -OH bond (originate from carboxyl group, hydroxyl group or chemically adsorbed water) which might be oxidized to superoxide anion radical ·OH. The peak located at 1380 cm−1 is belonged to monodentate nitrite species (M-N) resulted from the oxidation of adsorbed NH3 [45]. Among the peaks between 1400 ∼ 1850 cm−1, the peaks at 1580 cm−1, 1636 cm−1 and 1665 cm−1 are attributed to the NH bonds in the NH3 species of the Lewis acid site while the rests are belonged to NH4 + species on Bronsted acid site [69,70]. The contents of Lewis acid and Bronsted acid were calculated by peak areas and listed in Table 5 , and the change of Lewis acid contents is accordance with NH3-TPD results. And the contents of Lewis acid sites were significantly higher than that of Bronsted acid sites, indicating that the Mn/Ce ratios would significantly affect the composition of acid sites. Simultaneously, there is a general strengthening of the peak intensity of Lewis acid sites with adsorption time, suggesting that the Lewis acid sites are more stability than Bronsted acid sites, a similar viewpoint was also reported in the paper [71]. The variety of the NH3 adsorption state demonstrates that Mn/Ce ratios have a significant effect on the composition of acid sites of MnxCe1-xAC, especially for the Lewis acid sites. In situ DRIFTS study of reaction between NO + O2 and pre-adsorption NH3 The transient reaction between adsorbed species was further studied by in situ DRIFTS experiment at 80 °C. The peak at 947 cm−1 gradually became progressively weaker and even disappeared with the increase of NO + O2 co-adsorption time, manifesting that the adsorbed NH2 could react with NO and O2 to generate other nitrogen species. Peaks at 1380 cm−1, 1537 cm−1, 1619 cm−1, 1646 cm−1 and 1743 cm−1 were corresponded to free nitrate ions (NO3 −), bidentate nitrate, gaseous NO2 molecule, bridge nitrate and N2O4, respectively [72,73]. It can be observed that the peaks situated in 1537 cm−1, 1619 cm−1 were significantly enhanced with reaction time while the other peaks intensities remain unchanged, indicating that the bidentate nitrate and gaseous NO2 molecule increased. The peaks located at 1696 cm−1, 1717 cm−1 and 1872 cm−1 were attributed to the NO molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface [74], which can react with O2 to conduct “fast SCR” reaction [75], and the changes at 3000 ∼ 3400 cm−1 implying that adsorbed NH3 participated in the SCR reaction. With the prolong of NO + O2 co-adsorption time, the change degree of peaks (such as 947 cm−1, 1537 cm−1) over Mn0.7Ce0.3AC was more obvious compared with that of other catalysts, followed by Mn0.3Ce0.7AC, which was highly related to the adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst and the content of Lewis acid. These results indicated that NO and O2 would immediately react with the NH3 species adsorbed on the catalyst surface, the reaction rate is mainly governed by the mount of Lewis acid sites which is determined by the Mn/Ce ratios, and the residual NO gas proves that the adsorbed NH3 is completely consumed. The above analysis shows that the SCR reaction occurring on the catalyst surface follows the l-H mechanism: (Fig. 8 ) (1) NO ( g ) + N H 3 ( g ) + N O 2 ( g ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (2) NO ( g ) + N H 2 ( a ) → N H 2 NO → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) In situ DRIFTS study of reaction between NH3 and adsorption NO+O2 Fig. 9 exhibits the spectra of adsorbed NO + O2 and subsequent adsorption of NH3 to explore the reaction mechanism of NH3 and adsorbed NOx species. As is shown in Fig. 9(a), influx of NH3 affects the intensity of the peak to some extent, such as the peaks at 947 cm−1, 1696 cm−1, 1872 cm−1 and 3000 ∼ 3400 cm−1, which is attributed to the acid sites and the residual NO + O2. The peak located at 947 cm−1 increased significantly with the NH3 adsorption time but not completely consistent with the initial adsorption of ammonia. It is speculated that the NOx species on the catalyst surface may react with the adsorbed NH3 on Lewis acid sites. A slight increase in the peak at 1380 cm−1 indicates that the formation of NO3 −, suggesting that the reaction of ammonia with NO promotes the production of nitrate species. It is worth noting that the peaks at 1619 cm−1 and 1646 cm−1 disappear, which is presumed to be the reaction between NO2, bridge nitrate and adsorbed NH3. The peaks of Mn0.3Ce0.7AC change more violent in the interval of 3000 ∼ 3400 cm−1 since the high content of Lewis acid sites, suggesting the concentration of Lewis acid sites is the key to the NH3-SCR reaction [44]. From the above analysis results, the denitrification reaction on the catalyst surface was mainly determined by Lewis acid sites, which could be influenced by the Mn/Ce ratios significantly. The major reaction on the catalysts was as follows: (3) N H 3 ( a ) + N O 2 ( a ) → N O 2 ( N H 3 ) 2 + NO ( a ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (4) NH 4 + + NO 3 − ( a ) → N H 4 N O 3 + NO ( a ) + N H 3 ( a ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) Possible mechanism of the catalyst reaction Based on the above experimental results, the possible reaction mechanism on the prepared composite catalyst is inferred as follows, and the reaction mechanism diagram is placed in Fig. 10 . NH3 molecules are mainly in the form of adsorbed ligand NH3, ionic NH4 + and -NH2 which contributes to Lewis and Bronsted acid sites according to the in-situ DRIFTS NH3 adsorption results, and the Lewis acidic site controlled by Mn/Ce ratios performed a key role in the adsorption of ammonia which consistent with NH3-TPD analysis. Meanwhile, the NO molecules exist mainly as NO2, N2O4 and nitrate depending on the results of NO adsorption. When oxygen gas (O2(g)) enters the catalyst, the oxygen will be adsorbed and activated by oxygen vacancies produced by the active component proven to generate active oxygen (O2(a)) or chemisorbed oxygen, and the higher the unequal Mn/Ce ratio, the greater the reduction capacity and the more abundant chemisorbed oxygen species according to the XPS and H2-TPR results. The active oxygen may also react with the functional group -OH present in the activated carbon to form superoxide anion radical ·OH to facilitate the redox of Mnx+ and Cex+. Not only that, the adsorption and activation NH3 has been effectively improved due to the better mobility of the active oxygen species proven by previous outcomes. Under this action, NO will be converted into other nitrogen oxides (NO2, NO3 −) very quickly under the powerful redox ability and abundant Lewis acid sites, thus promotes the “fast SCR” reaction finally. This reaction was mainly controlled by l-H mechanism. The main specific reaction process is as follows: (5) N H 3 ( g ) → N H 3 ( a ) (6) N H 3 ( g ) + H + → NH 4 + ( a ) (7) NO ( g ) + O ( a ) → N O 2 ( a ) (8) N H 3 ( a ) + ( O ) → N H 2 ( a ) + OH ( a ) (9) O 2 ( g ) → O 2 ( ad ) → O ( a ) + − OH → · OH (10) N H 3 ( g ) + NO ( g ) + N O 2 ( g ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (11) N H 2 ( a ) + NO ( g ) → N H 2 NO ( a ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (12) N H 3 ( a ) + N O 2 ( a ) → N O 2 ( N H 3 ) 2 + NO ( a ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (13) NH 4 + + NO 3 − ( a ) → N H 4 N O 3 + NO ( a ) + N H 3 ( a ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) Conclusion The results of the prepared of carbon-based catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR using Cr-containing leather waste as raw carrier substances are a step forward in ensuring resource utilization and sustainable development. The low-temperature NH3-SCR performance of MnxCe1-xZr0.5/AC catalysts with different Mn/Ce ratios was investigated in this work. Mn0.7Ce0.3Zr0.5/AC exhibits the optimal low-temperature deNOx performance since the NO conversion efficiency at 200 °C can reach up to 97 %, and also shows good resistance to GHSV, H2O and SO2 poisoning. Physical structure characterization reveals that the catalyst features a large specific surface and excellent dispersion of active components, which is conducive to the tight binding between the elements which is one of the reasons for its superior catalytic activity. Results of catalyst surface property characterization (H2-TPR, NH3-TPD) demonstrate that Mn/Ce ratios can significantly affect the surface adsorption of oxygen species, the amount of Lewis acid sites and the redox ability of the catalyst, which subsequently determines the SCR performance as a result. At the same time, it is proved that there is a synergistic effect between Mn and Ce due to the electron transfer as mentioned in XPS, which contributes to the catalytic reactivity. The in situ DRIFTS results indicate that the Lewis acid site which could be promoted via metals co-doping with inequality ratio of Mn/Ce is the key of the entire NH3-SCR reaction, and the reaction mechanism is mainly controlled by Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. Finally, the as-prepared Mn0.7Ce0.3Zr0.5/AC catalyst might be one of the potential choices of NH3-SCR low temperature catalyst to some extent. coredata.dc:description: The resource utilization of Cr-containing leather waste is still a great challenge. In this work, waste from leather production as raw material was attempted to be used to synthesize activated carbon, a series of MnxCe1-xZr0.5/AC composite catalysts were prepared via loading three metal elements onto activated carbon by impregnation method, the NH3-SCR performance was measured in a low temperature range of 50 ∼ 200 °C. Among them, the catalyst Mn0.7Ce0.3Zr0.5/AC displays the optimal low-temperature SCR activity, excellent resistance to GHSV, H2O and SO2. The characterization results indicated that increasing the Mn/Ce inequality ratios within a certain range would promote the electron transfer between the active metal components, thereby enhancing the synergistic effect and the redox capacity of the catalysts, and it also could significantly improve the concentration of Lewis acid sites to accelerate the adsorption and activation of NH3, resulting in different catalytic activities. The in situ DRIFTS results prove that the Lewis acid site plays a vital role in the “fast SCR” reaction, and the whole reaction process conforms to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting the low-temperature NH3-SCR performance via metals co-doping with inequality Mn/Ce ratios in the carbon-based catalyst prepared by Cr-containing leather waste
